description:
Atethmia centrago, commonly known as the Lunar-spotted Pinion, is a species of moth belonging to the family Oecophoridae. It is found in Europe, including the United Kingdom, and parts of Asia.

The Lunar-spotted Pinion has a wingspan of approximately 30-35 millimeters. The forewings are pale greyish-brown, with darker brown patches and a distinctive pale crescent-shaped mark near the outer edge. The hindwings are greyish-brown. The species is known to be variable in its appearance, with some individuals having more distinct markings than others.

The larvae of A. centrago feed on the leaves and flowers of various plant species, including oak (Quercus), birch (Betula), and hawthorn (Crataegus). The moths are typically active at night and can be attracted to light sources.

This species is considered to be a common and widespread moth within its range, and it is not currently listed as a species of conservation concern.
